Executive Summary for Cytec Solvay Group - Willow Island, WV



1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

P2930 Process - Program Level 3

Facility ID #1000001066253



THIS IS A NEW PROCESS



We at Cytec Solvay Group are strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances; and ensure the safety of employees and neighbors.



2. The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled



The Willow Island Plant's Polymer Additives Unit manufactures polymer additive products, including ultraviolet light absorbers, antioxidants, anti-static agents, and depressant reactants.  P2930 is an intermediate product currently being manufactured at another location which is used at other Solvay sites to produce materials sold to the aerospace industry.  The Willow Island Plant proposes to manufacture P2930 in its Polymer Additives Unit in Building 82.  The process is located in Building 82 bays 28 through 32, floors 1 through 3 and the north yard adjacent to those areas.



The P2930 process uses chloroform which will result in the creation of a Program 3 Stationary Source at the facility. 



3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements of 

40 CFR part 68 of the EPA. The process was designed and constructed in accordance with ASME, NFPA and other nationally recognized safe design standards. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our facility.



Process Safety Informati

on



Process Safety Information pertaining to the hazards of the chemicals, the technology of the process, and the equipment of the process is compiled and maintained accessible to affected employees.  This includes access to SDSs for all materials handled. 



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)



PHAs are conducted in accordance with regulatory, company and business unit requirements, including compilation of Process Safety Information and participation including hourly personnel.  Action items from the PHAs are entered into an electronic follow up system to be tracked to completion.  The most recent PHA for the P2930 process was completed in August 2019 and used the What If/Checklist methodology.  PHAs are revalidated at least every five years.



Operating Procedures



The facility maintains written operating procedures that address various modes of operations, such as start up, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup following a shutdown.  These procedures are available to all operators for operating and training purposes and are periodically reviewed and certified annually as current and accurate. 



Training



The facility has a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the P2930 process.  This training program includes new hire orientation, classroom and on-the-job training.  Topics include an overview of the process and its hazards and the operating procedures.  Operators demonstrate their competency by examinations or field demonstrations and are given periodic refresher training.



Mechanical Integrity / Preventive Maintenance Program



Written mechanical integrity procedures follow consensus standards and corporate requirements, and recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.  These include periodic inspections of equipment and piping systems as well as preventive maintenance routines on instrumentation and other systems.  These routine

s are tracked using an electronic maintenance management program.  Training for individuals involved in maintenance activities includes an overview of the process and its hazards.



Management of Change (MOC)



The facility has a written MOC procedure to manage changes to chemicals, process technology, equipment, and procedures.  These changes are reviewed for potential impact on safety, health and the environment prior to being approved for implementation.  All approved changes are communicated to affected employees.  MOCs are tracked and documented using an electronic change management program.  



Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR)



PSSRs are conducted on new processes and on modifications to existing processes.  These PSSRs confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into service.  Action items identified in the PSSR are tracked to completion using an electronic follow up system.



Compliance Audits



The Willow Island Plant currently has processes covered by OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation (1910.119) which are subjected to a compliance audit every three years.  These audits are certified by site management and action items are tracked to completion in an electronic follow up system.  The P2930 process will be included in subsequent audits and incorporated into this audit schedule.  The next compliance audit is scheduled for July 2020.



Incident Investigation



The facility has written incident investigation procedures and will promptly investigate any incident that results in, or could reasonably have resulted in the accidental release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are conducted to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the situation from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.



Employee Participation



Employees are encouraged to participate in all aspects

of the Process Safety Management and accident prevention program.  This includes participation in PHAs, PSSRs, and Incident Investigations.  Employees also have access to all information created as part of the facility's accident prevention program.  



Hot Work Permit



The facility has a written Hot Work program which requires hot work permitting for jobs involving a potential source of ignition.



Contractors



The facility uses contractors to supplement its workforce for maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, their safety performance is evaluated.  Contract workers are given site-specific training including emergency procedures, site safety requirements and policies, and an overview of the process and its hazards. 



Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The chemical-specific prevention steps for reducing the risk of an accidental release of the regulated substance, chloroform, include:

?    Inventory management of chloroform in covered-process and peripheral areas

?    Design of specialized spill containment system which minimizes vapor generation

?    Containment of emergency relief devices

?    Carbon bed to reduce emissions

?    Fixed and portable leak detection equipment

?    Electrical classification for equipment

?    Fixed fire protection systems

?    Chemical-specific response procedures and personal protective equipment (PPE).



4. Five-year Accident History



The P2930 process is new and has no accidents within the past 5 years.



5. Emergency Response Program



The Willow Island Plant has a written emergency response program to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  These procedures include responses to a release of a regulated substance, fire, explosion, medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans, accountability for personnel, and notification of site and local emergency responders.



To ensure proper functioning, our emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  Suitab

le training is conducted regularly, for the different levels of responders. Drills are held regularly to ensure readiness for response. In addition, the emergency response plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our equipment or processes that would require a modified emergency response.



The overall emergency response program for the facility is coordinated with Pleasants County Emergency Management.  This coordination includes periodic meetings with local response officials, local government officials (LEPC), mutual aid associations (COVIEO) and industry representatives. Updated information pertaining to the P2930 process and chloroform handling has been submitted to Pleasants County and local volunteer fire departments have been provided a tour of the facility.



6.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The Willow Island Plant has ongoing activities to improve safety at the site.  As a member of OSHA's Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) Star Site since 2002, the site performs an annual evaluation of our safety performance and safety programs and develop action plans for the following year.  The facility also maintains current certifications under RC14001 and OHSA 18001.  Regarding accidental release prevention of regulated substances, the extensive PHA of the P2930 process developed action items which will be tracked to completion.
